content.value: Full of sugar and butter, and most likely to give someone a heart attack.
Inspired by
Adam Ragusea
225g salted butter - melted
2 cups (400 grams) brown sugar
2 eggs
1 tbsp vanilla essence
2 tsp salt
2 tsp (10 grams/2 packets) baking soda
2.5-3 cups white flour
350 grams chocolate of your choosing
Notes:
Browns sugar can be made here by using white sugar + molasses (roughly 3-4 tbsp)
Use good vanilla essence/extract, it makes a difference
The cookies are already sweet enough as it is, so choose chocolate wisely. 180 gram Tony Chocolonely Salted Caramel is just as good here.
Preheat the oven to a high grill
Mix the melted butter and brown sugar in a cake mixer until combined
Add the eggs, and beat until smooth
Add baking soda, vanilla, and salt and combine

Add 2 cups of the flour, and beat until smooth and combined. The mixture will most likely be runny still. Keep adding flour until the mixture is glossy, but doesn't stick easily to a finger (see notes)
Add chocolate chips, and then refrigerate the mix for 30 minutes to make it easier to handle
Turn out the dough into golf ball sized balls. Flatten into 1 cm thick pucks, and put onto a baking paper. Ensure enough spacing, the dough doubles in diameter whilst cooking
Repeat, for the rest of the dough, making various baking paper covered sheets of cookie dough. Roughly 6-9 cookies per sheet, depending on the oven size
Ensure the grill is hot and put the dough pucks under the grill for 1 minute, or until they start going brown and almost burning. Keep a close eye, they will burn if left too long
Repeat, setting each baking paper sheet aside after grilling
Set the oven to 180 degrees celsius, and let it cool down from the grill
Cook each sheet of cookie dough for at least 8 minutes. Dough will rise and spread out and form cracks. Looking into the cracks, you can see whether the cookie is done to your preference
Notes:
When mixing the flour in, if you want thinner cookies, then let the mixture be a little bit sticky. If you want thicker cookies, add a little more flour in, this is based on preference
Use multiple sheets of baking paper. When grilling the cookies, the dough will stick a bit to the baking paper, and thus it's easier just to transfer the entire sheet
During grilling, the dough generally won't increase in size here, but will during baking later. So don't rearrange the cookies, and be patient

When looking into the cookie dough crack, so long as the dough has expanded, the cookies should be cooked. The earlier the cookies are taken out, the more chewy they will be, but the risk of undercooking is also there. For slightly thinner cookies (dough just sticks to the finger), 8 minutes should be just enough to get chewy cookies
